security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with documentation and YAML templates. Contains one Python utility script that safely generates test cases from YAML files with no network access, no file system escape, and no code execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Educators spend hours creating varied exercises that apply cognitive science principles. This skill generates complete exercise sets with retrieval practice, spaced repetition, and difficulty progression using templates and evidence-based learning strategies.
actual_capabilities: Create 5-exercise sets with varied types (fill-in-blank, debug, build-from-scratch)
Apply evidence-based strategies (retrieval practice, interleaving, desirable difficulty)
Design difficulty progression from easy scaffolded exercises to stretch challenges
Generate test cases and assessment rubrics from YAML templates
Incorporate spaced repetition by tagging exercises with primary and secondary concepts
Validate exercises against quality standards (objectives, hints, rubrics, test cases)
limitations: Does not execute or test code - only designs exercise specifications
Focused on Python programming concepts - not specialized for other languages
Does not track learner progress or manage exercise repositories
Requires user to provide learning objectives and target audience

use_cases.title: Create homework assignments
use_cases.description: Design complete exercise sets for Python concepts with test cases, rubrics, and difficulty progression

use_cases.title: Build curriculum materials
use_cases.description: Apply evidence-based learning strategies to create courses with interleaved and spaced exercises

use_cases.title: Generate practice problems
use_cases.description: Create varied exercise types that target specific learning objectives for each lesson

prompt_templates.title: Basic exercise set
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 5 exercises for practicing list methods (append, remove, extend) for beginners. Include test cases and a rubric.

prompt_templates.title: Spaced repetition
prompt_templates.prompt: Design exercises for dictionaries (Lesson 4) that also review lists (Lesson 2) and conditionals (Lesson 3) using spaced repetition patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Evaluate quality
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate these 10 loop exercises for pedagogical effectiveness. Check variety, progression, evidence-based strategies, and test case coverage.

prompt_templates.title: AI-collaborative exercises
prompt_templates.prompt: Design 3 AI-collaborative exercises that teach students to work WITH AI as a co-learning partner per the Three Roles Framework.

output_examples.input: Create 5 exercises for practicing list methods for beginners
output: - Complete code with one blank for append/extend
- Hint: Consider what method adds items to a list
- Identify and fix bugs in remove method usage
- Write function to filter list based on condition
- Add new functionality to provided list code
Rubric: Correctness (40%), Code Quality (30%), Efficiency (20%), Error Handling (10%)

best_practices: Start with easy scaffolded exercises before progressing to build-from-scratch challenges
Apply at least two evidence-based strategies per exercise set (retrieval practice + interleaving)
Include progressive hints at three levels: gentle guidance, specific direction, and explicit approach
anti_patterns: Creating 5 identical exercise types in a row reduces engagement and learning
Skipping test cases leaves exercises unverified and potentially incorrect
Using only build-from-scratch exercises overwhelms beginners without proper scaffolding

faq.question: What exercise types does this skill support?
faq.answer: Fill-in-blank, debug-this, build-from-scratch, extend-code, trace-execution, explain-code, refactor, Parsons problems, and AI-collaborative exercises.

faq.question: What learning strategies are built into exercises?
faq.answer: Retrieval practice, spaced repetition, interleaving, elaboration, desirable difficulty, concrete examples, and dual coding.

faq.question: How does difficulty progression work?
faq.answer: Exercises progress through Bloom's taxonomy levels: Remember/Understand (easy), Apply (medium), Analyze/Evaluate/Create (hard). Each set includes starter, core, and stretch difficulty bands.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill that generates exercise specifications locally. It does not access files, network, or external systems.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing curriculum?
faq.answer: Provide learning objectives, target audience, and prior concepts. The skill designs exercises that apply spaced repetition by tagging primary and secondary concepts for review tracking.

faq.question: What makes this different from generic exercise generators?
faq.answer: This skill applies cognitive science research (testing effect, spacing effect, interleaving) to create pedagogically sound exercises with evidence-based design principles and quality validation.
